title: Monday, 11th March 2019

A trading statement this morning, and to nobody's surprise, it involves Kier's net debt.

PBateman Woodford special
JP11:15am

Higher than expected it seems, due to a reclassification of its net debt -- from £130m at the end of 2018 to £180.5m now.

BE11:15am

As in, post the rights issue in November that was meant to take the debt worries off the table?

11:15 am
JP11:15am

Yes exactly.

JP11:16am

This extra £50.5m or so was previously within development assets for sale, and has now been included on the balance sheet.

JP11:16am

Here's Peel Hunt:

11:16 am
JP11:16am

H1 update, n/c underlying FY 19 earnings and cash
Kier has provided an update ahead of its interims on 20 March.
Although underlying FY19 expectations are unchanged, two
items have been noted. First, as a consequence of hedging/other
adjustments (£10m) and debt classification within assets held for
resale (£40m), H1 net debt is now expected to be £180.5m vs
previous guidance of c£130m. However, given there is no change
to expected disposal proceeds or timings, there is no change to
FY19 net cash assumptions (PHe £19m). Second, a £25m nonunderlying contract provision re cash recoveries will be taken re
the Broadmoor project. Although largely completed and
management is confident in its position, an adjustment will be
made in the H1 results. We make no change to our cash,
dividend and underlying earnings expectations (94.3p) based on
PBT of £150m (cons £149.4m). Shares trading on 5.3x Jun’19
and 7.6% FY20 yield. We continue to see value.

RiskyBoy Re Kier: the CFO has £9k worth of stock. Says it all really.
JP11:17am

5.3x does seem very cheap...

BE11:17am

Rights issue was at 409p, if I remember correctly. And Woodford -- 15.4% holder last I checked -- as been buying all the way down.

11:18 am

Yes, I recall that too. It was the day after a short pitch on the stock from Vikram Kumar, of Kuvari Partners. Good timing: https://ftalphavil...-short-Kier-Group/

qwerty Kier cheap for a reason! Yield> PE is always a warning sign!

rw42 Did enjoy Jemima's latest bitcoin article - i think we need to coin a similar saying to pokers 'if you can't spot the sucker in the room' phrase for bitcoiners who are convinced that they are the only ones that can see the promised lands on the horizon.
JP11:19am

Debt classification change. H1 net debt is expected to be £180.5m (vs previous c£130m expectation). This largely (£40.2m) reflects a reclassification of the debt held within development assets held for resale. The debt had been consolidated within the assets, but is now included within net debt. Of this total, £9.8m relates to assets now sold, £14.1m relates to binding sales agreements (expected to complete by end-April), with the balance relating to assets either under offer or marketed for sale before the year end. This also affects the H1 average monthend net debt: £430m (vs previous £370m). Given this is an issue of timing and classification, we make no change to our year-end net cash assumptions of £19m.

11:19 am
JP11:20am

Cripes.

11:22 am
JP11:22am

For good measure, here's Stiefel -- PT 430p:

JP11:23am

Revision of net debt position. The group has revised its net debt position as at 31 December 2018 to £180.5m (from c.£130m). Its average net month-end net debt for the six months to 31 December 2018 has been re-calculated as c.£430m (from c.£370m). In the course of preparing its FY19E interim results, the company identifies a number of adjustments (c.£10.3m) primarily in relation to hedging activities. The group has also revised the classification of debt (c.£40.2m) associated with certain Development assets held for resale at 31 December 2018. Kier originally consolidated this debt balance within assets held for sale, following re-classification the debt has been included within the group's net debt position. This £40.2m net debt will unwind as the development assets are sold, with the majority expected to be disposed of by 30 June 2019.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @PBateman - I am sure the shorters will be busy bees today too. I guess we can thank QE and Brexit for making the UK a cheap casino to play in. It is your futures guys. Your grandkids and your children. Continue. I'll be adding to Kier because I see value too.
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Details of the accident have been limited thus far, though it was noted that the incident occurred shortly after take-off (~6 minutes) and followed a request by the pilot to return to the airport. In addition, it has been noted that the plane was relatively new (delivered in November 2018), had been in good condition (serviced last month) with no reported issues, and was flown by an experienced pilot. Lastly, parallels have been drawn to the Lion Air incident from last year especially given it was the same aircraft type and the accident occurred soon after departure, but we believe it is premature to make any such linkages.

TB Norwegian is the largest in Europe re Boeing 737
BE11:31am

What does this mean for Boeing shares? We are expecting a degree of weakness and volatility until there is clarity. Following the aforementioned Lion Air accident, we note that shares of Boeing stock experienced pressure and were down over 10% within weeks, which other factors contributed to as well. As regulators and other parties work to find the root cause of the accident, details of which should be forthcoming in days and weeks, we anticipate another round of volatility due to safety concerns, given this is the second fatal flight involving the 737 MAX following its EIS in May 2017.

BE11:31am

And UBS.

TB then you have Spicejet and FlyDubai
11:31 am
BE11:32am

Reports are early, but the similarities between the Lion Air and (now) Ethiopian
737MAX plane crashes are hard to ignore. Within minutes after takeoff, both the Lion
Air and Ethiopian pilots requested to return to their departure airport. Within 9
minutes and several minutes thereafter, respectively, Lion Air 610 and Ethiopian 302 had crashed. ... The Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System [MCAS] introduced on the 737MAX as a safety feature meant to kick-in at high angles of attack was the focus in the Lion Air crash and resulted in an Airworthiness Directive calling specific attention to the new system. The MCAS system doesn’t activate until the flaps used for takeoff are retracted, so in the case of Lion Air for example issues seemed to arise around the 2-3min mark. This appears to be a similar timeline to Ethiopian 302. It is unclear if additional training on MCAS was conducted at Ethiopian after the Lion Air accident.
The early reaction of Boeing’s stock will be negative (5%+?) on the back of the potential for a link between the crashes and financial implications to Boeing from any grounding (350 deliveries to date) or delivery delays (50+/mo being added to the fleet).

JP11:32am

(@FATDAZ, thanks for highlighting. Seems Southwest Airlines, Air Canada and GECAS have had the most delivered so far. Although, the data is from Wikipedia, so best to take with a pinch of salt.)

That range was representative of underlying issues in the approach to product and innovation diagnosed by the Board leading to and following Mr Dunkerton’s departure

Our conversations with investors and feedback from the company suggest there is strong support for the current strategy and management team. If Julian Dunkerton were to return to the business, we believe it could result in significant short-term operational disruption as: 1) the current team has been focused on delivering the Superdry 5.0 strategy for the past 18 months; 2) 31 senior leaders of the business (below the executive team) on an unsolicited basis to the board have “expressed their excitement” for the current strategy and leadership team; 3) all the directors have notified the board they would resign or not seek re-election to the board, if shareholders vote in favour of the resolutions.

11:42 am
JP11:43am

Over the past two weeks we have been closely evaluating every single Tesla retail location, and we have decided to keep significantly more stores open than previously announced as we continue to evaluate them over the course of several months. When we recently closed 10% of sales locations, we selected stores that didn’t invite the natural foot traffic our stores have always been designed for. These are stores that we would have closed anyway, even if in-store sales made up our entire sales model. A few stores in high visibility locations that were closed due to low throughput will be reopened, but with a smaller Tesla crew. In addition, there are another 20% of locations that are under review, and depending on their effectiveness over the next few months, some will be closed and some will remain open.

Once growth starts slowing for the cycle, it is likely to keep on

In terms of the macro view .....

BE11:57am

Experian's US business has seen the benefit of a strong US economy, the impact of trended data, the benefit of the Equifax breach, and new product roll-out. The alignment couldn't have been better for the company, in our opinion.
However, we believe US data will start to come in incrementally weaker over the next few months. Delinquencies are beginning to edge up (albeit still at historically low levels), Financial Services employment growth is now running below overall employment growth (historically a negative lead), and we are seeing sequential weakness in areas like temporary labour. The US economy is not as strong as it was, in our view.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

The proposed deal gives
Charter Court shareholders 0.8253 new OSB shares for each Charter Court share,
representing 45% of the new and enlarged group. Both OSB and Charter Court
are in the very unfashionable and unloved Buy-to-Let mortgage space, both are
growing rapidly and both have market leading levels of operating efficiency. While
this may lead the reader to conclude that there would not be significant cost
synergies we observe that they address the market in a different manner (Charter
Court digitally, OSB manually) and have slightly different cost strengths (OSB does
much of its processing in India). We believe a deal like this would create value
with synergies. E.g. Charter Court applications that cannot be underwritten digitally
could be passed to OSB to manually review, and initial OSB applications could pass
through the Charter Court model with many not needing manual oversight. Our
stress test analysis suggests that OSB's risk-adjusted margin and capital position
are strong enough to weather both substantial economic and property market
related storms. Our forecasts see impairment increasing to 27bps this year from
the 7bps recorded in 2017 and break-even occurs with impairment of c.244bps, 35x
the 2017 impairment charge. We believe OSB offers good risk-adjusted value with
a 2018 PE of 6.7x and a dividend yield of 5.0%, before any deal synergies.

Blank canvas Thanks for everything today, from both sides of the page
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Canaccord Genuity view

Pre-synergies, we estimate the Enlarged Group trades at 6.3x CY19 P/E falling to 5.9x CY20 and at 1.3x CY19 P/BV for a 21% ROE.
Potential value creation for OSB shareholders will come primarily in our view from 1) greater scale, which may afford greater pricing power and hence net interest margin protection, 2) cost synergies which could be significant. We forecast OSB’s standalone cost-income ratio to be c.31% in 2019 and 2020. Interestingly, however, the joint statement does not refer explicitly to cost synergies.
We believe it is well known that the OSB management team have long held ambitions for M&A. However, we believe the support of the board for this particular merger is an admission that net loan book growth and margin protection are becoming more difficult.
We expect the UK macro backdrop to become increasingly challenging over the next 12 months. Therefore, despite being buyers of OSB on a stand-alone basis, we question at this point in the cycle whether OSB shareholders would want exposure to an additional £6.2bn of post-crisis loans from CCFS (as at 30 Sep, OSB’s last reported net loan book at 30 Sep was £8.5bn), the underwriting quality of which has not been tested through the cycle.
In conclusion, we would encourage OSB shareholders to consider taking advantage of any share price strength seen on the back of the proposed merger. Paragon (BUY, TP 495p) remains our preferred play in the specialist lenders sub-sector.

BE12:07pm

A proposed merger has been announced between the two cheapest and (in our
view) the two most outstanding banks in our coverage. Although both OSB and
Charter Court (Buy) offer excellent performance metrics on a stand-alone basis,
we believe that the combination should prove materially value-enhancing for
both sets of shareholders. OSB shareholders will hold c.55% of the combined
group, to be led by OSB’s highly regarded CEO Andy Golding. BUY.
 In truth, we were mildly surprised that OSB and CCFS did not agree to combine
prior to CCFS’ IPO in September. Be that as it may, since then, both banks have
delivered exceptional loan growth while maintaining ROTEs of 26-30%. In the
context of such sustained performance, OSB and CCFS’ existing valuation metrics,
5.2/5.4x 2020e EPS respectively, make absolutely no sense to us, and we expect
the proposed combination to provide a suitable catalyst for an overdue re-rating.
